Text:
When you have a `jar` file in this case, it's simply a library. The servlet container isn't looking in your `jar` file for a `web.xml` file. That's simply not how it works. As you describe, your `web.xml` file must reference the filter explicitly otherwise the servlet container won't know to load it. 

If you're trying to use annotation-based loading, per the spec, referenced in [this post][1], it must be in `WEB-INF/classes` of the `war` file which your library is not, because it's in a separate `jar`. You might be able to achieve this if you configure your system to unpack `jar` files and repack all of them into a single `war` file.


  [1]: https://developer.jboss.org/thread/229917?tstart=0&_sscc=t

When you have a `jar` file in this case, it's simply a library. The servlet container isn't looking in your `jar` file for a `web.xml` file. That's simply not how it works. As you describe, your `web.xml` file must reference the filter explicitly otherwise the servlet container won't know to load it. 

If you're trying to use annotation-based loading, per the spec, referenced in [this post][1], it must be in `WEB-INF/classes` or in `WEB-INF/lib` as a `jar`.


  [1]: https://developer.jboss.org/thread/229917?tstart=0&_sscc=t
Comment: Edited a misquote from my source
